---
title: 'Implementing Virtual Reality in K-12 Classrooms: Lessons Learned from Early
  Adopters'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-QMMLFMQK" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Stranger-Johannessen, E., &#38; Fjørtoft, S. O. (2021). <div id="csl-bib-meta-QMMLFMQK" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-QMMLFMQK" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Stranger-Johannessen and Fjørtoft explored how teachers in K-12 schools are using virtual reality (VR) in their classrooms. They interviewed nine teachers who were among the first to adopt VR technology, using head-mounted displays (HMDs) to enhance learning. The study found that VR was used for various subjects but typically only for part of the lesson. Due to limited HMDs, students often took turns using the devices while others worked on related tasks. This setup required careful planning and student self-regulation. Teachers faced technical and ethical challenges, such as dealing with firewalls and privacy concerns. Despite these issues, the authors suggest that early adoption of VR is crucial for educational innovation. This study highlights the potential and challenges of integrating VR into everyday teaching.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-QMMLFMQK" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Virtual Reality, K-12 Education, Early Adopters, Teaching Methods, Educational Technology
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-QMMLFMQK" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    There is very little research on K-12 education outside designated research studies on how teachers use VR for learning. This study addresses gap in research by asking: How did teachers start with VR and how do they use it? We interviewed nine teachers from different primary, lower secondary, and upper secondary schools—who had one to five years of experience with VR—among the first to include VR in their teaching, making them early adopters. All schools used HDMs, but the number, brand, and model varied. VR was used to teach various subjects and topics, but mostly for a limited part of the lesson. Due to the limited number of HMDs, the teaching was often organized as stations, where the students took turns using the HMDs and working on other tasks related to the theme. This requires good planning from the teacher and a certain degree of self-regulation among the students, as the teacher’s eyes and ears are on the student(s) wearing the HMDs. The early adoption of VR sometimes encountered challenges related to technical (e.g., firewalls) or ethical issues (e.g., privacy), but some argued that for innovation to happen, it was necessary to “act first and ask later”.
  </article>
